Spear with a thick wooden (bamboo?) two part shaft, wooden foresahft, and metal point.  The shaft is made of two pieces of wood, joined together by braided fiber rope and an unknown adhesive.  This rope extends, becomes a thick braid, winds around the shaft multiple times, and eventually secures the haft point between the metal point and the foreshaft, serving as lashing.  The end of the shaft into which the foreshaft inserts is wrapped with two strips of woven rattan.  The foreshaft tapers to a point at the proximal end which inserts into the shaft -- the two parts detach.  As mentioned, the join between the foreshaft and point is lashed with thick fiber robe.  The point has a four sided shaft/tang that becomes a large, triangular head with extending barbs at the base.; card indicates that the handle was cut off on account of packing, but it appears to be intact.

At the point, this lashing also serves to connect the tang of the metal point to an oblong wood foreshaft which inserts into the opening of the bamboo shaft.  The point is triangular with a long sharp tip and with two barbs extending down and out from the base.  The metal has been coated with some substance that makes it glossy.;

description:
Display shield with small weapons and artifacts attached. 


Plaque or shield, flat with edges shaped in various ways (bottom curved, top squared off in the corners -- reminiscent of medieval heraldic shield or device), made out of wood.  The backside has two cross pieces of wood and one length of metal wire that would have been used to hang the item up.  The front side is covered with baldy faded velvet (once red, now orange).  There is ivory trim along the edges in places.  The front is totally filled with various items, all of which are miniatures.  Most (all?) have numbers written on them in small letters, perhaps identifying them.  The items include musical instruments made of wood, metal, ivory, and bamboo in the top center.  There is clothing made of cotton in the top and left right.  There is also a leather purse in the top left and a wood and leather addle in the top right.  The very center has carved wood shields with black painted geometric and abstract designs.  Down the right and left sides are various weapons -- wood spears with metal tips, swords and blades of various shapes and forms of metal with ivory handles, arrows of darts of thin wood shafts with ivory points.  The bottom center has tools with metal blades or hooks and ivory handles.  Below that is a wooden quiver with ivory tip and two wooden arrows inside and also a carved wooden item on a metal pivot that may be a cannon.  Along the verb bottom is a wooden bow with a metal string and one long wooden arrow with ivory point above the bow.;

This bowl was purchased by Melvin R. Gilmore from Bearsbelly at Armstrong on the Ft. Berthold Reservation, August 18, 1921. It belonged to the mother-in-law of Bearsbelly, who died in 1905.

description:
1 of 4 spears with removable heads. 

Complex spear (arrow?). Long bamboo shaft.  

The very distal end is wrapped with woven fiber. Fiber woven in such a ay to form bumps that stick out. This is then covered with an unknown substance.  

The next section of the shaft is wrapped around with a multi-strand section of braided fiber. It is wrapped tightly at first, but loosely later on. Near the end a small wooden dowel is attached with fiber cord. At the very end a metal point with a hollow tang and a barb is attached. One end of the dowel inserts into the hollow opening of the point. The other end of the dowel inserts into the distal end of the shaft, so that it forms a fore-shaft and then a point. 

Both ends of the dowel are tapered. The very end (proximal) has a carved groove forming a neck. 

Has feather fletching at the proximal end, lashed on at both ends with fiber.; Similar to 8195 which is classified as a harpoon.
